content.description: Stay just right of the crack, climb following the bolt line (staying right of the crack, left of the neighboring bolted routes).  Pull the small roof.  Supposedly the route originally went up left after the last bolt, but it seems most people just head straight up and slightly right to the anchor now.
content.location: Just right of a prominent (dirty and often wet) crack on the right side of New Buck.

content.protection: standard rack, but smallish   anchor at top to left of large dead tree

content.description: Climb (mantle) the ledge, then up and left to a flake, lay this back to the anchor.
content.location: 10 feet left of the Autopilot handcrack, below a ledge 7 feet up.

content.description: Follow the handcrack up to and past an overhang. Trend right after a tree (dead as of Sept. 2017, may be gone in the future) up to the fixed anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack with an emphasis on hand sized pro. Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: Handcrack starts at the top of a hump next to a large tree, a few feet left of the start of Welcome Matt.

content.description: Best climb at New Buck.  Tricky finger pockets and long reaches.
content.protection: Tri-cams to protect pockets and cams used.

content.description: Gain the finger crack via small holds.  Go to top of crack, step right to first bolt.  Friction up through pockets, horizontals and large crystals clipping a few more bolts on the way to fixed anchors.  Longest route on the cliff and a fun climb.
content.protection: Protect the thin crack down low with gear and clip bolts the rest of the way
content.location: At the right end of the cliff, on a less than verical face with an obvious vertical finger crack beginning ten feet up.  Just left of the small right arching, right facing corner that begins Fawn Crack.

content.description: Follow the left and middle cracks to the top.
content.location: Leftmost of three cracks (often wet and dirty)

content.description: Up some vertical cracks and small ledges to a fixed anchor.
content.location: Right end of the cliff, the end of the climbable face.

content.description: Identified as the right-facing corner (that starts a couple bodylengths up) just R of Autopilot.  Getting into the corner is the crux.  The 8+ direct start was too mossy, even on the very dry day we were there, to consider.
content.protection: Great gear once you're in the corner.  Until you get there... well, there's that first bolt on the route next to it.
content.location: Fixed anchor just left of the top (shared with Autopilot).

content.description: Climb thin moves to a shrubbery in a big hole/hueco about halfway up. Continue to the top on slab.
content.location: Third route from the right with bolts on it.  Look for the big hole with the shrubbery.

content.description: Climb small vertical crack and flakes, trending slightly left, to a bulge. Climb through the bulge using pockets (crux), to fixed anchor.
content.protection: Bolted, might want some small cams for head gear.

content.description: Climb a small corner to a stance beneath an right rising finger crack.  Make a couple strenous and painful moves to pull a small overhang and gain the crack (crux).  Continue up the crack to friction climbing protected with bolts to fixed anchors.
content.protection: Protect the finger crack with a couple pieces and continue on clipping bolts.
content.location: Five feet up and right of Ten Point Buck at a small right arching, right facing corner topped with a crack in a slight overhang.

content.description: Climb to ledge, traverse right, then up face past horizontal crack to another diagonal crack and easier climbing to the anchor.
content.location: Below a ledge 7 feet up, 10 feet left of Autopilot.  Same start as Tuesday Layback.

content.description: Start at the middle crack then trend right to the rightmost crack passing numerous ledges. Find a tree and belay, then walk off (right or left).
content.location: Just right of Team Rocksport below three vertical cracks.

content.description: Climb the crack and face passing huecos, small ledges, and three bolts to a fixed anchor.
content.location: Near the right end of the wall, as you begin up the gully.

content.description: Steep, thin start to slab, with some thought-provoking bolt spacing.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Welcome Matt, or just to the left of J. D. Memorial Route (which has a prominent shrubbery growing out of a hole in the middle of it).
Handcrack near the middle of the wall

content.description: This cliff is great for having many moderates close together, with a few short lines that pack a punch. A great season opener for the volume of climbing you can get in within a day. Although the cliff is a mere 60 feet tall, the rock quality is good and climbing fun. This area is mostly concealed by the tree line and can get buggy.
